did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, Va.
did.abstract: The Yancey Family Papers contains correspondence between members of the Yancey family, accounts, receipts, the will of Christopher Taliaferro, and a facsimile Confederate Ten Dollar note. The material dates from 1808 to 1912.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Permission to publish material from the Yancey Family Papers must be obtained from Special Collections, Virginia Tech.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Yancey Family Papers, Ms1987-059, Special Collections, Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The Yancey Family Papers collection was acquired by Special Collections prior to 1987.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The processing, arrangement, and description of the Yancey Family Papers was completed in October 2013.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Yancey Family Papers contains correspondence between members of the Yancey family, accounts, receipts, the will of Christopher Taliaferro, and a facsimile Confederate Ten Dollar note. The collection dates from 1808 to 1912.

The correspondence spans 1850 to 1866. The letters included in this collection are written by Dr. C. D. Everett and his wife, Mary Everett, to C. D. Everett's sister, Martha Yancey, and William Yancey, Dr. Everett's brother-in-law. Dr. Everett's letters mostly pertain to financial matters and Dr. Everett's antagonistic relationship with his father who, according to Dr. Everett, has chosen to "vilify, slander and abuse, and finally kick out of doors all of his children." After a hiatus during the Civil War, Dr. Everett and Mary resumed correspondence in 1866 with the Martha and William Yancey.

The bank note from the Bank of Kentucky also directly relates to the Yancey Family, as it is signed by William Yancey. It is unclear how the Christopher Taliaferro will (1813) and the 1886 tax receipt for Mr. W. W. Werden are related.
